title: MP57-03 DECISION AIDS FOR PROSTATE CANCER SCREENING: A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW AND META-ANALYSIS
abstract: You have accessJournal of UrologyProstate Cancer: Detection & Screening V1 Apr 2018MP57-03 DECISION AIDS FOR PROSTATE CANCER SCREENING: A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW AND META-ANALYSIS Jarno Riikonen, Gordon Guyatt, Tuomas P Kilpeläinen, Samantha Craigie, Arnav Agarwal, Thomas Agoritsas, Rachel Couban, Philipp Dahm, Petrus Järvinen, Victor Montori, Nicholas Power, Patrick O Richard, Jarno Rutanen, Henrikki Santti, Thomas Tailly, Philippe D Violette, Qi Zhou, and Kari A O Tikkinen Jarno RiikonenJarno Riikonen More articles by this author , Gordon GuyattGordon Guyatt More articles by this author , Tuomas P KilpeläinenTuomas P Kilpeläinen More articles by this author , Samantha CraigieSamantha Craigie More articles by this author , Arnav AgarwalArnav Agarwal More articles by this author , Thomas AgoritsasThomas Agoritsas More articles by this author , Rachel CoubanRachel Couban More articles by this author , Philipp DahmPhilipp Dahm More articles by this author , Petrus JärvinenPetrus Järvinen More articles by this author , Victor MontoriVictor Montori More articles by this author , Nicholas PowerNicholas Power More articles by this author , Patrick O RichardPatrick O Richard More articles by this author , Jarno RutanenJarno Rutanen More articles by this author , Henrikki SanttiHenrikki Santti More articles by this author , Thomas TaillyThomas Tailly More articles by this author , Philippe D ViolettePhilippe D Violette More articles by this author , Qi ZhouQi Zhou More articles by this author , and Kari A O TikkinenKari A O Tikkinen More articles by this author View All Author Informationhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.juro.2018.02.1815AboutPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissionsReprints ShareFacebookTwitterLinked InEmail INTRODUCTION AND OBJECTIVES Prostate cancer screening decision is preference-sensitive. Decision aids may facilitate screening decision by providing information on the risks and benefits of screening. We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of RCTs that addressed the impact of decision aids on decisional outcomes and the men's screening decision. METHODS We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Cochrane CENTRAL up to June 2017. We performed screening of articles, data extraction, and assessment of risk of bias using a modified Cochrane risk of bias tool and quality of decision aids using IPDAS instrument independently and in duplicate. We asked authors to verify the accuracy of our extracted data. From the RCTs in which appropriate decision aids were compared to usual care, we abstracted knowledge about prostate cancer screening, screening discussion during clinical encounter, decisional conflict, and screening decision. We analyzed effects using the DerSimonian-Laird's random effects inverse variance method for continuous outcomes (standardized mean differences with 95% confidence intervals (CI)), and for dichotomous outcomes using the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method (relative risk and 95% CI). RESULTS Of 7,825 reports from 6 databases, 19 RCTs proved eligible (n=12,662). In all 19 studies, allocation sequence was adequately generated, in almost half allocation was adequately concealed (47%) and data collectors blinded (42%). We were able to evaluate 9 decision aids: they reported the aim (100%) and the consequence of screening (89%) well, however, only 22% reported chances of having true or false negative test result, or the next step if screening test is negative. None of the aids were designed to facilitate shared decision making between patients and physicians. In the pooled analyses (Figure), decision aids moderately increased knowledge, and demonstrated a small decrease in decisional conflict. Decision aids had no effect on discussion about screening but resulted in a small decrease in willingness to undergo screening. CONCLUSIONS Moderate quality evidence suggests modest impacts of existing decision aids. Work in this area would benefit from decision aids that not only provide education to patients, but also promote shared decision making in the patient-physician encounter. © 2018FiguresReferencesRelatedDetails Volume 199Issue 4SApril 2018Page: e764-e765 Advertisement Copyright & Permissions© 2018MetricsAuthor Information Jarno Riikonen More articles by this author Gordon Guyatt More articles by this author Tuomas P Kilpeläinen More articles by this author Samantha Craigie More articles by this author Arnav Agarwal More articles by this author Thomas Agoritsas More articles by this author Rachel Couban More articles by this author Philipp Dahm More articles by this author Petrus Järvinen More articles by this author Victor Montori More articles by this author Nicholas Power More articles by this author Patrick O Richard More articles by this author Jarno Rutanen More articles by this author Henrikki Santti More articles by this author Thomas Tailly More articles by this author Philippe D Violette More articles by this author Qi Zhou More articles by this author Kari A O Tikkinen More articles by this author Expand All Advertisement Advertisement PDF downloadLoading ...
